answer_html: And so we see that there are two inflection points, one at x = 1 and one at x = 3.
answer_latex:
And so we see that there are two inflection points, one at \emph{x} = 1
and one at \emph{x} = 3.
hints_html:
The previous part gave us the derivative of

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'(x) = x^{3} - 6x^{2} + 9x = x(x^{2} - 6x + 9) = x(x-3)^{2}.\end{aligned}\]

Now, we take the second derivative, set it to zero and look at where the sign changes.
hints_latex:
The previous part gave us the derivative of

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
f'(x) = x^{3} - 6x^{2} + 9x = x(x^{2} - 6x + 9) = x(x-3)^{2}.
\end{align*}

Now, we take the second derivative, set it to zero and look at where the

hints_raw:
The previous part gave us the derivative of

:<math> \displaystyle
f'(x) = x^{3} - 6x^{2} + 9x = x(x^{2} - 6x + 9) = x(x-3)^{2}.
</math>

Now, we take the second derivative, set it to zero and look at where the sign changes.
question: 4 (iii)
sols_html:
The previous part gave us that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'(x) = x^{3} - 6x^{2} + 9x = x(x^{2} - 6x + 9) = x(x-3)^{2}.\end{aligned}\]

Let’s compute the second derivative of the function:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f''(x) = 3x^2 -12x + 9\end{aligned}\]

and then factor it

\[\begin{aligned} f''(x) &= 3x^2 -12x + 9\\ &= 3(x^2-4x+3) \\ &= 3(x-1)(x-3)\end{aligned}\]

This is plenty enough to get the sign table of the second derivative.

[c]@llllll@ & & \(\displaystyle 1\) & & \(\displaystyle 3\) &
\(\displaystyle 3(x-1)\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle 0\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & & \(\displaystyle +\)
 \(\displaystyle (x-3)\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle 0\) & \(\displaystyle +\)
 \(\displaystyle f'(x)\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle 0\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle 0\) & \(\displaystyle +\)
 \(\displaystyle f(x)\) & \(\displaystyle \cup\) & & \(\displaystyle \cap\) & & \(\displaystyle \cup\)

And so we see that there are two inflection points, one at x = 1 and one at x = 3.
sols_latex:
The previous part gave us that

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
f'(x) = x^{3} - 6x^{2} + 9x = x(x^{2} - 6x + 9) = x(x-3)^{2}.
\end{align*}

Let's compute the second derivative of the function:

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
f''(x) = 3x^2 -12x + 9
\end{align*} and then factor it

\begin{align*}
f''(x) &= 3x^2 -12x + 9\\
&= 3(x^2-4x+3) \\
&= 3(x-1)(x-3)
\end{align*}

This is plenty enough to get the sign table of the second derivative.

\begin{longtable}[c]{@{}llllll@{}}
& & $\displaystyle 1$ & & $\displaystyle 3$ &\\
$\displaystyle 3(x-1)$ & $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle 0$ &
$\displaystyle +$ & & $\displaystyle +$\\
~$\displaystyle (x-3)$ & $\displaystyle -$ & & $\displaystyle -$ &
$\displaystyle 0$ & $\displaystyle +$\\
~$\displaystyle f'(x)$ & $\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle 0$ &
$\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle 0$ & $\displaystyle +$\\
~$\displaystyle f(x)$ & $\displaystyle \cup$ & & $\displaystyle \cap$ &
& $\displaystyle \cup$\\\\
\end{longtable}

And so we see that there are two inflection points, one at \emph{x} = 1
and one at \emph{x} = 3.

</math>

Let's compute the second derivative of the function:
:<math>\displaystyle
f''(x) = 3x^2 -12x + 9
</math>
and then factor it
:<math>\begin{align}
f''(x) &= 3x^2 -12x + 9\\
&= 3(x^2-4x+3) \\
&= 3(x-1)(x-3)
\end{align}</math>

This is plenty enough to get the sign table of the second derivative.

And so we see that there are two inflection points, one at ''x'' = 1 and one at ''x'' = 3.
statement_html:
Consider the function

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \frac{1}{4}x^{4} - 2x^{3} + \frac{9}{2}x^{2}.\end{aligned}\]

iii) Find the x-values of all the inflection points of f(x).

Note: if inflection points do not exist, say so.
statement_raw:
Consider the function
:<math>
f(x) = \frac{1}{4}x^{4} - 2x^{3} + \frac{9}{2}x^{2}.
</math>

iii) Find the x-values of all the inflection points of f(x).

''Note: if inflection points do not exist, say so.''
